alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for employee bonuses
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers providing bonus payments to employees
title: Expenses and benefits: bonuses

table.body:
As an employer providing bonus payments to your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

This includes both cash and non-cash bonuses.
table.title: Overview

table.body:
What you have to deduct, pay and report to HMRC depends on the kind of bonus you give your employee.

##Cash bonuses (including vouchers exchangeable for cash)

The bonus you've paid counts as earnings, so:

- add it to your employee's other earnings
- deduct and pay PAYE tax and Class 1 National Insurance through payroll

##Non-cash bonuses

There are different rules depending on the item you give. Follow the reporting and payment [rules for the specific item](/expenses-and-benefits-a-to-z "Expenses and benefits A to Z").

^ In certain cases you’ll have to use PAYE when giving non-cash bonuses, eg if you give your employee something they can easily convert to cash. ^

*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
